pageContent._comments: JSON object that contains data for page labels, buttons, etc.

_common.name: Transformation using the auto map feature
_common.shortDescription: Learn how to use a Mapping node to create a new JSON Object message in a message flow driven by an XML message over HTTP.
_common._resourceToOpenComment: The ID of the first resource to open when the user imports the tutorial. Resource IDs are defined in the repo_metadata.json Tutorials listing on ot4i.

pageDetails._topicListComment: A short list of product concepts or tasks demonstrated by this tutorial
pageDetails._outcomesComment: Start learning some product basics with a very simple Toolkit use case

outcomeList.title: Use App Connect Enterprise to automatically map between source and target data structures using a graphical mapping tool which bases its auto map feature upon matching similar names and knowledge of synonyms.

summary._overviewComment: A short description of what happens in this tutorial, and an optional short explanation of the IIB concepts used in this tutorial if necessary for context. What background knowledge must the user have for this to make sense?

sections.section: This tutorial focusses on how to use the auto map capabilities of the IBM App Connect Enterprise Graphical Mapping Node. It provides JSON schema and XML schema metadata for input and output message structures which include fields with similar but non-matching names. The detailed configuration for auto map is described and the mapped outcomes demonstrated.

overview.name: Create
overview.heading: Import project
overview._createComment: A description of what will happen when the user clicks Import.

sections.section: Click Import and the AutoMappingExample application will be imported into your workspace. Each of these flows contains a mapping node, which have source and target structures pre-configured, but the mapping has not yet been completed. This is deliberate as the instructions in the Run section will demonstrate how to use the auto-map feature in a variety of ways for completing the creation of these maps.
The AutoMappingExample1 message flow will be opened for you.

overview.name: Prepare
overview.heading: Prepare an Integration Server to test the message flow

details.details: Later in this tutorial we will test the message flows using a local integration server, which is created from within the Toolkit. If you're using a Toolkit earlier than version 11.0.0.7, then you will need to open an App Connect Enterprise Command Console and start an integration server that way. This alternate option is detailed in the Knowledge Center, but we will progress in this tutorial assuming you're using our most up to date Toolkit capabilities.

From the Integration Explorer view in the bottom left corner of the Toolkit, right-click the Integration Servers folder and select the option to Create a local integration server. Leave all the options with their default values and click Finish. The local Integration Server will be started, using a project in your Toolkit's workspace as the work directory. Click OK to dismiss the Success dialog.

overview.name: Run
overview.heading: Try out the auto map feature in a variety of ways which demonstrate its detailed capabilities
overview._runComment: The full steps for the user to run through the tutorial. Use 'sections' to render paragraphs, 'steps' with a type of 'ordered' or 'unordered' to render HTML lists, and 'substeps' to render nested lists.

details.details:
Double click the mapping node in the AutoMappingExample1 message flow and the map will open. In the map source data structure (shown on the left side of the map), right click the field in the source which is named MYLASTNAME and select the Auto Map option. The Auto Map wizard will open and the first page will be titled Automatically map inputs to outputs. Alter the settings on this page as follows:
Name Matching Options:
    Case sensitive checkbox = NOT SELECTED
    Alphanumeric characters = SELECTED
    Create transforms when the names of inputs and outputs are the same = SELECTED
    Create transforms when the names of inputs and outpus are more similar than = NOT SELECTED
    Create transforms when the input and output names are matched to synonyms defined in a file = NOT SELECTED

Click Next. At the top of the dialog page a red cross will appear with the error There are no matches satisfying the selected options. Click Cancel.

Explanation for what we just saw:
The Name Matching options have specified that the names of input and output must be the same, although the check is not case sensitive. MYLASTNAME in the input JSON schema has no direct match in the output XML schema, whose closest match is MYLASXXXX.
Now we have seen this, click Cancel to return back to the map view ready for the next demonstration.

sections.section: Demonstrate the option for non-exact matching, using a percentage match

details.details:
Back in the map (AutoMappingExample_Mapping.map), in the map source data structure (shown on the left side of the map), right click the field in the source which is named MYLASTNAME and select the Auto Map option. The Auto Map wizard will open and the first page will be titled Automatically map inputs to outputs. Alter the settings on this page as follows:
Name Matching Options:
    Case sensitive checkbox = NOT SELECTED
    Alphanumeric characters = SELECTED
    Create transforms when the names of inputs and outputs are the same = NOT SELECTED
    Create transforms when the names of inputs and outpus are more similar than = SELECTED (Place the slider at the default 60%)
    Create transforms when the input and output names are matched to synonyms defined in a file = NOT SELECTED

Click Next. At the top of the dialog page a red cross will appear with the error There are no matches satisfying the selected options. Click Cancel.
Move the slider from 60% down to 40%. Click Next. The dialog will now show a matching transform to MYLASXXXXX.

Explanation for what we just saw:
The Name Matching options have specified that the names of input and output do not need to be exactly the same.
In the first part of the test, with the slider set to a demand of 60%, there were no matches
In the second part of the test, with the slider set to a demand of 40%, there was a match to MYLASXXXX (5 out of 10 letters is greater than 40% similarity).
Now we have seen this, click Cancel to return back to the map view ready for the next demonstration.

sections.section: Demonstrate the option for case sensitive matching

details.details:
Back in the map (AutoMappingExample_Mapping.map), in the map source data structure (shown on the left side of the map), right click the field in the source which is named MyLaSxXxXx and select the Auto Map option. The Auto Map wizard will open and the first page will be titled Automatically map inputs to outputs. Alter the settings on this page as follows:
Name Matching Options:
    Case sensitive checkbox = SELECTED
    Alphanumeric characters = SELECTED
    Create transforms when the names of inputs and outputs are the same = SELECTED
    Create transforms when the names of inputs and outpus are more similar than = NOT SELECTED
    Create transforms when the input and output names are matched to synonyms defined in a file = NOT SELECTED

Click Next. At the top of the dialog page a red cross will appear with the error There are no matches satisfying the selected options.

Change the options as follows:
Name Matching Options:
    Case sensitive checkbox = NOT SELECTED
    Alphanumeric characters = SELECTED
    Create transforms when the names of inputs and outputs are the same = SELECTED
    Create transforms when the names of inputs and outpus are more similar than = NOT SELECTED
    Create transforms when the input and output names are matched to synonyms defined in a file = NOT SELECTED

Click Next. The dialog will now show a matching transform to MYLASXXXXX.

Explanation for what we just saw:
In the first test, we were seeking an exact match to the letters, compared in a case sensitive fashion and so there was no exact match for MyLaSxXxXx
In the second test, we changed the comparison to not be case sensitive and so there was a match between MyLaSxXxXx and MYLASXXXXX.
Now we have seen this, click Cancel to return back to the map view ready for the next demonstration.

sections.section: Demonstrate the option for using a file of synonyms

details.details:
Back in the map (AutoMappingExample_Mapping.map), in the map source data structure (shown on the left side of the map), right click the field in the source which is named name and select the Auto Map option. The Auto Map wizard will open and the first page will be titled Automatically map inputs to outputs. Alter the settings on this page as follows:
Name Matching Options:
    Case sensitive checkbox = NOT SELECTED
    Alphanumeric characters = SELECTED
    Create transforms when the names of inputs and outputs are the same = SELECTED
    Create transforms when the names of inputs and outpus are more similar than = NOT SELECTED
    Create transforms when the input and output names are matched to synonyms defined in a file = SELECTED
    Filename = <YourToolkitWorkspaceLocation>\AutoMappingExample\MySynonyms.txt

Click Next. The dialog will now show a matching transform to label.

Explanation for what we just saw:
The file MySynonyms.txt was used to correlate the source message field named name with the field in the target message named label.
Now we have seen this, click Cancel to return back to the map view ready for the next demonstration.

GOT TO HERE ... DESCRIBE FLOW2 automap across the board and then deploy and test that one ... The imported message flow Example_JSONObject_Mapping should still be open. At the top of the flow canvas, click the Flow Exerciser icon . If prompted (which you will be if your Toolkit has known connections to more than one server), select the TEST_SERVER integration server that you just created and agree to the confirmation dialog which warns that the message flow is owned by an Application. After a few seconds another confirmation dialog will appear with a Ready to record message status. Read through the information on the dialog and click Close.

Back at the top of the flow, click on the Send Message icon and when the dialog opens, select the provided input message:
<Message><Country><Name>UK</Name><Greeting>Hello</Greeting></Country></Message>
Click Send to push the data into the flow.

You should receive a reply message from the flow. The XML will have been transformed into a JSON Object messag :
{"Message":{"Country":{"Name":"UK","Greeting":"Hello"}}}
